episodes.title: Introduction to Meeting Starters
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.610 --> 00:00:04.410
John Spence, trusted consultant,
respected advisor,

2
00:00:04.410 --> 00:00:08.270
experienced strategist,
passionate speaker, well-read author,

3
00:00:08.270 --> 00:00:13.290
a top 100 business though leader, helping
executives achieve most success everyday.

4
00:00:15.327 --> 00:00:16.885
>> I'd like take about two minutes and

5
00:00:16.885 --> 00:00:20.615
give you a quick overview of this
program to help you make a good decision

6
00:00:20.615 --> 00:00:23.685
about whether it would be the right
investment for your organization.

7
00:00:23.685 --> 00:00:26.415
These videos are based on
four programs I've taught for

8
00:00:26.415 --> 00:00:27.691
companies around the world.

9
00:00:27.691 --> 00:00:32.240
Advanced leadership,
high-performance teams, my formula for

10
00:00:32.240 --> 00:00:36.420
business excellence and
a big high-tier called moments of truth.

11
00:00:36.420 --> 00:00:40.860
Each of the videos is designed to be used
at a weekly, monthly, quarterly meeting

12
00:00:40.860 --> 00:00:45.510
to deliver some solid training, great
ideas, that your people can go back and

13
00:00:45.510 --> 00:00:49.600
implement right away to have a significant
positive impact on your business.

14
00:00:49.600 --> 00:00:53.230
These workshops are information intensive,
highly interactive, fast paced.

15
00:00:53.230 --> 00:00:56.540
It's gonna get your people engaged,
discussing things.

16
00:00:56.540 --> 00:01:01.060
Not just sit and watching a video, but
get them hands on, not only thinking about

17
00:01:01.060 --> 00:01:05.370
these great ideas, but figuring out how
they can apply them in your organization.

18
00:01:05.370 --> 00:01:07.487
I hope this helped you decide if
this would be a good investment for

19
00:01:07.487 --> 00:01:07.998
your company.

20

episodes.description: A clear explanation of specifically how to help a work group or team become a high-performance team. Covers the role of the team, the purpose of the team and the six key elements of a high-performance team.
episodes.title: How to Build and Sustain a High Performance Team
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.220
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03.220 --> 00:00:06.207
In this session were gonna talk
about what it takes to build and

3
00:00:06.207 --> 00:00:07.880
sustain a high performance team.

4
00:00:07.880 --> 00:00:11.060
First thing we look at what is the role
of the team in other words what

5
00:00:11.060 --> 00:00:12.760
are they supposed to accomplish?

6
00:00:12.760 --> 00:00:14.810
Might be a strategy team and it's down and

7
00:00:14.810 --> 00:00:17.586
look to the long term
future of the organization,

8
00:00:17.586 --> 00:00:21.750
creates strategic objectives and
a basic framework of a plan.

9
00:00:21.750 --> 00:00:25.450
Might be a decision-making team,
it's their job to take that strategy,

10
00:00:25.450 --> 00:00:29.380
those ideas and
decide whether to implement them or not.

11
00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:32.870
Might be an innovation team, their
job is to blue-sky and brainstorm and

12
00:00:32.870 --> 00:00:34.610
come up with wild ideas.

13
00:00:34.610 --> 00:00:36.680
Or it might be an implementation team.

14
00:00:36.680 --> 00:00:39.284
It's their job to take the ideas,
the strategy,

15
00:00:39.284 --> 00:00:43.202
the information that someone else has
made a decision on and implement it.

16
00:00:43.202 --> 00:00:48.049
Key idea here, I've seen a lot of
trouble in teams when they don't

17
00:00:48.049 --> 00:00:50.640
understand why they were formed.

18
00:00:50.640 --> 00:00:54.625
Greatest example is an implementation
team that's spending a whole bunch time

19
00:00:54.625 --> 00:00:58.990
blue-skying and talking about strategy
when they're not the one that

20
00:00:58.990 --> 00:01:01.650
sets a strategy and
they're the one that makes the decisions.

21
00:01:01.650 --> 00:01:05.890
So, the first thing you wanna do is back
up and say, why did we form this team?

22
00:01:05.890 --> 00:01:08.130
Number two is,
what is the structure of the team?

23
00:01:08.130 --> 00:01:12.440
And there's really sort of a continuum
here that starts at independent,

24
00:01:12.440 --> 00:01:14.990
then interdependent, then dependent.

25
00:01:14.990 --> 00:01:17.180
I like to use a sports analogy for this.

26
00:01:17.180 --> 00:01:21.920
If you look at different types of teams,
an independent team would be a golf team.

27
00:01:21.920 --> 00:01:25.300
Yes I'm on the team, and
I'm trying to play for a team score, but

28
00:01:25.300 --> 00:01:26.990
I'm also playing for my own score.

29
00:01:26.990 --> 00:01:30.920
It's basically me versus the course,
no one else can hit the ball for me,

30
00:01:30.920 --> 00:01:33.090
nobody else can sink a putt for me.

31
00:01:33.090 --> 00:01:37.310
I can get a little advice but at the end
of the day it's my individual score

32
00:01:37.310 --> 00:01:40.500
that gets added to the team score
which means the team could lose but

33
00:01:40.500 --> 00:01:42.080
I could still have the lowest score and

34
00:01:42.080 --> 00:01:46.180
I would get an award I'm completely
independent from the rest of the team.

35
00:01:46.180 --> 00:01:50.010
Great example of an interdependent
team would be a baseball team.

36
00:01:50.010 --> 00:01:52.110
When I'm up at the plate, I'm alone.

37
00:01:52.110 --> 00:01:53.540
I'm basically independent.

38
00:01:53.540 --> 00:01:57.890
It's me against the pitcher,
nobody can bat for me, nobody can run for

39
00:01:57.890 --> 00:02:00.280
me, the coach can give me advice but

40
00:02:00.280 --> 00:02:02.940
at the end of the day,
I'm the only one at the plate.

41
00:02:02.940 --> 00:02:07.390
However, when I'm in the field with the
rest of the team, we are interdependent.

42
00:02:07.390 --> 00:02:10.150
I've gotta be able to field the ball,
throw it to first base.

43
00:02:10.150 --> 00:02:13.830
If I'm out in the outfield, and a pop fly
comes out and I just watch it go by, and I

44
00:02:13.830 --> 00:02:19.740
don't do anything, my lack of effort, not
playing with the team, can cost the team.

45
00:02:19.740 --> 00:02:23.910
So an interdependent team, has elements of
independence, while I'm doing my own work,

46
00:02:23.910 --> 00:02:26.750
but I also have elements
of interdependence where

47
00:02:26.750 --> 00:02:31.020
my performance impacts the rest of
the team and the performance of the other

48
00:02:31.020 --> 00:02:35.470
players on the team, the other members
of the team impacts my performance.

49
00:02:35.470 --> 00:02:38.780
Finally you have a dependent team and
on a dependent team,

50
00:02:38.780 --> 00:02:41.805
everybody's performance is
impacted by everybody else's.

51
00:02:41.805 --> 00:02:45.980
Two great examples for these would be
a football team or a basketball team.

52
00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:48.890
You can even say a soccer team because if

53
00:02:48.890 --> 00:02:52.500
one player decides not to play
it impacts the entire team.

54
00:02:52.500 --> 00:02:55.340
If one basketball player decides they're
not gonna run to the other end of

55
00:02:55.340 --> 00:02:57.120
the court they won't pass the ball or

56
00:02:57.120 --> 00:03:01.400
they won't take any shots or one football
player decides they're not gonna block.

57
00:03:01.400 --> 00:03:05.250
Or another great wanna be a relay
like an Olympic relay running relay.

58
00:03:05.250 --> 00:03:08.650
If the first two runners out of the floor
do great, and the third runner decides

59
00:03:08.650 --> 00:03:11.580
they're not gonna run,
I'm not thinking they're winning a metal.

60
00:03:11.580 --> 00:03:15.490
So you've gotta look at,
what is the structure of our team?

61
00:03:15.490 --> 00:03:20.330
Are we an independent team, an
interdependent team, or a dependent team.

62
00:03:20.330 --> 00:03:23.970
One last thing to look at before we look
at the high performance team model is

63
00:03:23.970 --> 00:03:24.770
compensation.

64
00:03:25.820 --> 00:03:27.330
This is a big one.

65
00:03:27.330 --> 00:03:31.100
There's a thing called the law
of unintended consequences.

66
00:03:31.100 --> 00:03:35.860
If you compensate a team individually,
I don't care how

67
00:03:35.860 --> 00:03:40.510
much you try to make them of the team, but
if I work well and I get more money and

68
00:03:40.510 --> 00:03:44.730
it doesn't matter what happens to
the rest of the team, it is not a team.

69
00:03:44.730 --> 00:03:49.070
Now the reverse is I can pay someone
a special bonus for doing well but

70
00:03:49.070 --> 00:03:52.730
if I don't tie a large part of their
compensation to the performance of

71
00:03:52.730 --> 00:03:56.460
the entire team, then you're
basically gonna create infighting and

72
00:03:56.460 --> 00:04:00.970
it's everyone for themselves because
their compensation rewards them for

73
00:04:00.970 --> 00:04:03.460
being individually good,
not good on the team.

74
00:04:03.460 --> 00:04:08.090
So compensation is another big factor in
how a team interacts with each other.

75
00:04:08.090 --> 00:04:13.090
Now I'd like to share with you the high
performance team model I've built after 20

76
00:04:13.090 --> 00:04:17.690
years of working with teams,
from the Fortune 500 down to start ups,

77
00:04:17.690 --> 00:04:21.470
every type of company you can possibly
imagine, basically all over the world.

78
00:04:21.470 --> 00:04:24.780
And as I looked at all these different
teams, the good ones, the bad ones,

79
00:04:24.780 --> 00:04:28.010
the high performance ones,
the dysfunctional ones, I looked for

80
00:04:28.010 --> 00:04:34.010
a pattern of what the best consistently
did that allowed them to be the best.

81
00:04:34.010 --> 00:04:41.499
There are six elements to this model, and
if you spell it out it's D-M-C-C-M-D.

82
00:04:41.499 --> 00:04:44.770
The first D stands for direction.

83
00:04:44.770 --> 00:04:46.465
If you're gonna have an effective,

84
00:04:46.465 --> 00:04:49.865
high-performance team,
they need to have a clear, specific,

85
00:04:49.865 --> 00:04:55.630
well-communicated Vision and strategy for
growth and it has to be shared.

86
00:04:55.630 --> 00:04:58.580
That doesn't mean the team gets to set
the direction of the team, per se, it

87
00:04:58.580 --> 00:05:03.230
may be someone higher in the organization
that tells the team the outcome they want.

88
00:05:03.230 --> 00:05:06.640
But the team needs to have a say in
the outcome if they're gonna have a stake

89
00:05:06.640 --> 00:05:07.590
in the outcome.

90
00:05:07.590 --> 00:05:11.370
So step one is to get a shared
direction for the team.

91
00:05:11.370 --> 00:05:12.260
The M and

92
00:05:12.260 --> 00:05:17.230
this whole model is basically built on
the two Ms, the first M is measurements.

93
00:05:18.460 --> 00:05:23.360
The only way to have a true high
performance team is to set very clear

94
00:05:23.360 --> 00:05:28.780
goals that are specific, measurable and
the keyword here is binary.

95
00:05:28.780 --> 00:05:32.650
It's one, zero, black,
white, yes, no, no guessing.

96
00:05:32.650 --> 00:05:37.800
Here's one my very favorite business
phrases, ambiguity breeds mediocrity.

97
00:05:37.800 --> 00:05:42.550
And on a high performance team,
you do not have any ambiguity.

98
00:05:42.550 --> 00:05:46.880
Everybody knows exactly what the goals of
the team are, what the outcomes look like,

99
00:05:46.880 --> 00:05:50.680
how's it's gonna be measured, what the
budget is, what the time line as clear,

100
00:05:50.680 --> 00:05:51.750
specific, measurable.

101
00:05:51.750 --> 00:05:55.470
And the keyword again here is binary
because you can't have any guessing.

102
00:05:55.470 --> 00:05:56.050
No guessing.

103
00:05:56.050 --> 00:05:57.970
You either got the goal or you didn't.

104
00:05:57.970 --> 00:06:00.870
And you're gonna see why this is so
important in just a minute.

105
00:06:00.870 --> 00:06:02.550
The two Cs are pretty straightforward.

106
00:06:02.550 --> 00:06:04.000
The first one if competence.

107
00:06:04.000 --> 00:06:06.840
I wanna get the best people I
can possibly get on my team.

108
00:06:06.840 --> 00:06:10.350
Now, that doesn't mean that everybody
has to have four advanced degrees from

109
00:06:10.350 --> 00:06:11.970
Ivy league colleges.

110
00:06:11.970 --> 00:06:15.300
What it means is for
the position they have on the team,

111
00:06:15.300 --> 00:06:18.640
I want to get the very best
person I can for that position.

112
00:06:18.640 --> 00:06:20.720
The next C is communication.

113
00:06:20.720 --> 00:06:23.940
And there's a couple of key words here,
open, honest,

114
00:06:23.940 --> 00:06:28.270
robust, candor,
the big one is transparency.

115
00:06:28.270 --> 00:06:30.910
The more information you share
with people on the team,

116
00:06:30.910 --> 00:06:33.360
the higher level of
accountability you can have.

117
00:06:33.360 --> 00:06:36.190
If someone on the team didn't
get enough information,

118
00:06:36.190 --> 00:06:39.920
they really don't know what's going on,
someone didn't tell them about the goal,

119
00:06:39.920 --> 00:06:42.850
they didn't give them enough information
on the project, you're withholding

120
00:06:42.850 --> 00:06:47.400
information, you cannot hold that
person accountable, they don't know.

121
00:06:47.400 --> 00:06:50.950
But if you give lots of information,
you share as much information as you

122
00:06:50.950 --> 00:06:53.850
possibly can,
you share it with everybody on the team.

123
00:06:53.850 --> 00:06:56.790
Then you can have very high
levels of accountability.

124
00:06:56.790 --> 00:07:00.230
It used to be that people said
that knowledge was power.

125
00:07:00.230 --> 00:07:04.180
No, sharing knowledge allows
you to empower other people,

126
00:07:04.180 --> 00:07:05.870
which multiplies your power.

127
00:07:05.870 --> 00:07:09.060
And on a team,
we want to have as much empowerment and

128
00:07:09.060 --> 00:07:11.650
as much sharing of
information as possible.

129
00:07:11.650 --> 00:07:15.100
Okay, here's the big leverage
in the model, the next M and

130
00:07:15.100 --> 00:07:17.650
that is mutual accountability.

131
00:07:17.650 --> 00:07:21.310
That's when you create a team and it's
really three levels of accountability.

132
00:07:21.310 --> 00:07:24.000
Level one is personal accountability.

133
00:07:24.000 --> 00:07:28.030
I hold myself personally accountable for
delivering what I promised.

134
00:07:28.030 --> 00:07:32.970
If I accept a goal and I say I'm gonna
get it done I work really hard to hold

135
00:07:32.970 --> 00:07:38.160
myself accountable to keep my word,
deliver on my promise, deliver that goal.

136
00:07:38.160 --> 00:07:43.350
Level two is mutual is accountability,
and that's where everybody on the team,

137
00:07:43.350 --> 00:07:47.185
regardless of ranks, seniority, doesn't
matter if we're on the team together,

138
00:07:47.185 --> 00:07:49.795
we all hold each other accountable for

139
00:07:49.795 --> 00:07:52.325
achieving the goals we
all agreed on together.

140
00:07:52.325 --> 00:07:55.845
That's why those specific measurable
binary goals are so important,

141
00:07:55.845 --> 00:07:57.555
no ambiguity, no guessing.

142
00:07:57.555 --> 00:08:00.142
Because when I understand
everybody else's goal and

143
00:08:00.142 --> 00:08:04.562
they understand my goal, then I can hold
them accountable and they can hold me

144
00:08:04.562 --> 00:08:07.862
accountable because we all know what
we're supposed to be doing together.

145
00:08:07.862 --> 00:08:11.052
The third level of accountability on a
high performance team, and this is really

146
00:08:11.052 --> 00:08:16.102
what differentiates a work group from a
team to a high performance team, is where

147
00:08:16.102 --> 00:08:21.120
you expect even encourage other people
on the team to hold you accountable.

148
00:08:21.120 --> 00:08:24.600
That means that if somebody walks in your
office and says, hey, you were supposed to

149
00:08:24.600 --> 00:08:29.400
get this done by noon on Tuesday and it's
4 o'clock on Thursday, where's the report?

150
00:08:29.400 --> 00:08:31.246
You were supposed to have
it to me two days ago.

151
00:08:31.246 --> 00:08:31.950
You don't get mad.

152
00:08:31.950 --> 00:08:33.600
You don't get angry.

153
00:08:33.600 --> 00:08:34.450
You don't get defensive.

154
00:08:34.450 --> 00:08:36.170
You say, thank you.

155
00:08:36.170 --> 00:08:37.250
You're exactly right.

156
00:08:37.250 --> 00:08:39.710
I did promise that on Tuesday,
it is Thursday.

157
00:08:39.710 --> 00:08:41.450
My fault, I apologize.

158
00:08:41.450 --> 00:08:44.830
I will make that my number one
priority and get it done right away.

159
00:08:44.830 --> 00:08:49.510
Now I'm gonna tell you why the first M of
measurable goals is so important because

160
00:08:49.510 --> 00:08:53.330
if you don't have those clear, specific,
measurable, binary goals, if you have

161
00:08:53.330 --> 00:08:57.310
any ambiguity, what it sounds like is, hey
I don't think you're trying hard enough.

162
00:08:57.310 --> 00:09:00.390
Doesn't seem to me like that
report was turned in on time.

163
00:09:00.390 --> 00:09:03.090
I don't feel like you're
really giving it 100%.

164
00:09:03.090 --> 00:09:07.630
When the goals are unambiguous,
there is no guessing, there's no think,

165
00:09:07.630 --> 00:09:08.530
feel, or seem.

166
00:09:08.530 --> 00:09:09.890
You either got it or you didn't.

167
00:09:09.890 --> 00:09:11.650
It's data, it's facts.

168
00:09:11.650 --> 00:09:14.700
That means you can be rigorous,
but not ruthless.

169
00:09:14.700 --> 00:09:17.960
You can hold people fully
accountable without attacking them.

170
00:09:17.960 --> 00:09:22.140
You can say, you're okay, but
your performance was not acceptable.

171
00:09:22.140 --> 00:09:25.350
I like you, but I don't appreciate
it when you turn things in two,

172
00:09:25.350 --> 00:09:27.670
or three days late,
it hurts the whole team.

173
00:09:27.670 --> 00:09:31.790
A lot of people really struggle with
accountability, holding other people

174
00:09:31.790 --> 00:09:35.980
accountable, cuz they think they're being
mean and when you have clear, specific,

175
00:09:35.980 --> 00:09:39.360
measurable, agreed upon goals,
where everybody knows what they are.

176
00:09:39.360 --> 00:09:42.040
They're black or white,
yes or no, no guessing.

177
00:09:42.040 --> 00:09:44.830
I've said this multiple times
because it's so critical, but

178
00:09:44.830 --> 00:09:48.590
if you can take all the ambiguity out,
then you can really

179
00:09:48.590 --> 00:09:51.720
have a high level of accountability
without attacking each other.

180
00:09:51.720 --> 00:09:55.830
And last but not least in the model
is the final D, which is discipline,

181
00:09:55.830 --> 00:09:59.240
the discipline to actually build
this into the team, maintain it,

182
00:09:59.240 --> 00:10:04.560
put it on the agenda, talk about it, make
it part of the team culture all the time.

183
00:10:04.560 --> 00:10:05.880
Here's what happens.

184
00:10:05.880 --> 00:10:09.900
In mediocre teams,
when there's an emergency, there's a fire,

185
00:10:09.900 --> 00:10:12.690
they pull together and
they act like a high performance team.

186
00:10:12.690 --> 00:10:15.480
They are hitting on all cylinders,
they're helping each other,

187
00:10:15.480 --> 00:10:18.670
high levels of accountability,
lots of communication, but that's rare.

188
00:10:18.670 --> 00:10:24.905
The reverse is in high performance teams,
they act this way 85-90% of the time.

189
00:10:24.905 --> 00:10:27.015
And every now and then,
they slip a little bit.

190
00:10:27.015 --> 00:10:30.225
And then they hold each other accountable
and get right back up to high performance.

191
00:10:30.225 --> 00:10:35.030
So those are some of the key ideas
around the role of the team,

192
00:10:35.030 --> 00:10:38.530
the structure of the team,
compensation of the team and

193
00:10:38.530 --> 00:10:41.910
my high performance team model of DMCCMD.

194
00:10:43.230 --> 00:10:46.768
I hope this helps you build better
teams in your organization and

195
00:10:46.768 --> 00:10:49.074
sustain them as high performance teams.

196
00:10:49.074 --> 00:10:59.074
[MUSIC]

00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.454
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03.454 --> 00:00:06.637
In this section I'd like to talk to
you about the key characteristics of

3
00:00:06.637 --> 00:00:08.340
highly effective leaders.

4
00:00:08.340 --> 00:00:12.390
This is based on a proprietary research
study I did with several thousand

5
00:00:12.390 --> 00:00:15.380
high potential employees at top
companies around the world.

6
00:00:15.380 --> 00:00:19.120
These are folks that you would love,
love to have in your company.

7
00:00:19.120 --> 00:00:19.620
They're so

8
00:00:19.620 --> 00:00:23.230
good at what they do, they basically
could get a job anyplace they wanted to.

9
00:00:23.230 --> 00:00:27.370
They're what I call voluntary employees,
because if they didn't like their job,

10
00:00:27.370 --> 00:00:30.940
they would just leave today and
have a job at the competition by tomorrow.

11
00:00:30.940 --> 00:00:35.050
And by the way, 88% of people that
quit their job don't quit the job,

12
00:00:35.050 --> 00:00:37.697
don't quit the hours, don't quit the pay,
don't quit [LAUGH] the workload.

13
00:00:37.697 --> 00:00:38.520
You know what they quit?

14
00:00:38.520 --> 00:00:41.005
Their idiot boss,
their manager, their leader.

15
00:00:41.005 --> 00:00:45.020
[LAUGH] So, this is especially
important to cover these things.

16
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:49.130
I asked them, if you could work anywhere
you want to work, and with any leader

17
00:00:49.130 --> 00:00:52.910
you wanted to work with, basically, why
do you work for the folks you work for?

18
00:00:52.910 --> 00:00:55.800
What are the characteristics you look for
and

19
00:00:55.800 --> 00:00:58.710
the kind of leader that you
would willingly follow?

20
00:00:58.710 --> 00:01:00.690
After I compiled all the answers,
and looked for

21
00:01:00.690 --> 00:01:05.770
a pattern, it basically boiled
down to seven Cs of leadership.

22
00:01:05.770 --> 00:01:08.580
The first C is character, and
it's the most important one.

23
00:01:08.580 --> 00:01:13.500
You might also use the word credibility
here, but here's what they told me.

24
00:01:13.500 --> 00:01:16.050
The single most important thing I look for

25
00:01:16.050 --> 00:01:19.810
in a leader I would
willingly follow is honesty.

26
00:01:19.810 --> 00:01:24.160
I want someone who will tell me the truth,
who has high integrity,

27
00:01:24.160 --> 00:01:26.100
has high character.

28
00:01:26.100 --> 00:01:28.650
I can believe them
because they're credible.

29
00:01:28.650 --> 00:01:30.560
Why?
Because they're honest.

30
00:01:30.560 --> 00:01:34.790
The second C is competence, you gotta
be really, really good at what you do.

31
00:01:34.790 --> 00:01:37.050
Now, this doesn't mean you gotta
be able to do everybody's job,

32
00:01:37.050 --> 00:01:42.040
but there are two skill sets you
must be exceedingly competent in.

33
00:01:42.040 --> 00:01:45.350
Your job, whatever that might entail,
whatever your work duties are,

34
00:01:45.350 --> 00:01:48.900
you've gotta be, and the word I like
to use is toweringly competent.

35
00:01:48.900 --> 00:01:52.970
And then you've gotta be exceedingly
competent at your leadership skills.

36
00:01:52.970 --> 00:01:56.240
Here's the best advice I can
give you around competence.

37
00:01:56.240 --> 00:02:00.540
Never in the history of the world has
there been more fantastic information

38
00:02:00.540 --> 00:02:02.570
available for free.

39
00:02:02.570 --> 00:02:06.330
If you're going to be an effective leader
who demonstrates competence, you've

40
00:02:06.330 --> 00:02:11.040
also got to be dedicated to lifelong
learning, to what I call, personal Kaizen.

41
00:02:11.040 --> 00:02:15.760
Continuous incremental improvement, always
trying to get better, Reading, studying,

42
00:02:15.760 --> 00:02:18.320
watching videos, listening to audio books.

43
00:02:18.320 --> 00:02:22.370
Everything you can do to get more
competent at your job duties, and

44
00:02:22.370 --> 00:02:25.225
dramatically more competent
in your leadership skills.

45
00:02:25.225 --> 00:02:30.055
The third C is courage, and what the folks
on the survey told me was, of course,

46
00:02:30.055 --> 00:02:31.785
I want someone who is courageous.

47
00:02:31.785 --> 00:02:33.875
I want a leader who could
make bold decisions,

48
00:02:33.875 --> 00:02:37.875
take big risks, make tough calls.

49
00:02:37.875 --> 00:02:41.915
But really they said and
this is fascinating, is I expect that, but

50
00:02:41.915 --> 00:02:46.510
what I really want is a leader who is
courageous enough to be vulnerable,

51
00:02:46.510 --> 00:02:49.580
to be authentic,
to admit they don't have all the answers.

52
00:02:49.580 --> 00:02:50.600
That they need some help, or

53
00:02:50.600 --> 00:02:54.130
they might be in over their head,
or they're a little confused, too.

54
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:57.890
Now I wouldn't do this all the time, 90%
of the time, I don't know what's going on!

55
00:02:57.890 --> 00:03:03.610
But what they're saying is most of
the time I want a bold, courageous

56
00:03:03.610 --> 00:03:08.320
leader who's got a clear vision, that's
strong, and knows where they're going.

57
00:03:08.320 --> 00:03:11.820
But I also want them to be authentic and
vulnerable enough,

58
00:03:11.820 --> 00:03:16.150
courageous enough, to ask for help,
to say they need some assistance.

59
00:03:16.150 --> 00:03:19.090
For them to say, hey, you're smart people,
that's why I hired you,

60
00:03:19.090 --> 00:03:23.150
that's why you're on my team,
I'd love your feedback, your input,

61
00:03:23.150 --> 00:03:27.780
your assistance on this, to help me
with this one area where I'm struggling.

62
00:03:27.780 --> 00:03:29.390
The third C was courage.

63
00:03:29.390 --> 00:03:31.920
The fourth C was communication.

64
00:03:31.920 --> 00:03:35.790
Again, what the folks in the survey
said was I expect my leader to be

65
00:03:35.790 --> 00:03:40.180
a great communicator,
to be inspirational, to be motivational,

66
00:03:40.180 --> 00:03:44.450
to be able to share a clear vision
of the future, where we're going.

67
00:03:44.450 --> 00:03:49.100
But the most important skills I look for
in a leader that I would willingly follow

68
00:03:49.100 --> 00:03:53.860
are asking great questions and
being an intense listener,

69
00:03:53.860 --> 00:03:56.440
being curious, wanting to know
what other people are thinking.

70
00:03:56.440 --> 00:03:58.280
I have just said it around courage is,

71
00:03:58.280 --> 00:04:02.650
if you are a great leader,
you hire really smart talented people.

72
00:04:02.650 --> 00:04:06.360
Why in the world would you not ask them
for their input and their ideas, and

73
00:04:06.360 --> 00:04:11.840
then when they give it to you, listen
very, very closely to it and implement it.

74
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:14.500
The fifth C is collaboration.

75
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:17.420
This is a big one and again,
remember in all these, I'm

76
00:04:17.420 --> 00:04:21.310
getting feedback from the top employees
of the top companies around the world.

77
00:04:21.310 --> 00:04:23.620
People that are very good at what they do,

78
00:04:23.620 --> 00:04:26.080
the kind of folks that anyone
would wanna have on their team, so

79
00:04:26.080 --> 00:04:30.710
they've got some pretty high expectations
for what they look for in their leader.

80
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:34.530
In the area of collaboration, what they
said is, I understand you're the boss,

81
00:04:34.530 --> 00:04:37.140
I know you own the company, or
you're the senior vice president, or

82
00:04:37.140 --> 00:04:40.410
you're my manager, but
don't lord that over me.

83
00:04:40.410 --> 00:04:43.720
What they said is most of the time,
I want my leader to be a partner,

84
00:04:43.720 --> 00:04:47.930
a peer, to get in there shoulder to
shoulder with me, roll up their sleeves,

85
00:04:47.930 --> 00:04:52.310
do the work, and really be part of
the team and collaborate with us.

86
00:04:52.310 --> 00:04:56.045
The sixth C is an interesting one,
compassion, thank you millennials.

87
00:04:56.045 --> 00:04:59.680
[LAUGH] What they said in this survey was

88
00:04:59.680 --> 00:05:02.450
I'm not going to give my
life to your company.

89
00:05:02.450 --> 00:05:04.500
You need to be a compassionate leader, and

90
00:05:04.500 --> 00:05:06.666
understand that my job
is just part of my life.

91
00:05:06.666 --> 00:05:11.200
I have a family, I have a hobby,
i donate my time,

92
00:05:11.200 --> 00:05:14.440
I've got a sport I wanna play,
whatever it might be.

93
00:05:14.440 --> 00:05:16.760
I'm gonna work hard while I'm there, but

94
00:05:16.760 --> 00:05:19.870
do not expect me to stay until 10 at
night, work through the weekends, and

95
00:05:19.870 --> 00:05:22.640
do those things,
you are not gonna drive me in the ground.

96
00:05:22.640 --> 00:05:26.560
Remember, these are the best of the best,
so they have options.

97
00:05:26.560 --> 00:05:29.600
If they don't enjoy where they're working,
they don't like their leader,

98
00:05:29.600 --> 00:05:33.520
they're not having fun, they feel like
they're being just crushed and overworked,

99
00:05:33.520 --> 00:05:36.850
that they don't have a compassionate
leader, they will start looking for

100
00:05:36.850 --> 00:05:39.460
a job immediately and
leave as fast as they can.

101
00:05:39.460 --> 00:05:45.780
What compassion says is, understand me,
recognize my value, help me get better,

102
00:05:45.780 --> 00:05:51.940
invest in me, be a partner, be on my
side and show me that you care about me.

103
00:05:51.940 --> 00:05:55.140
You care about me at the office, but
you care about me as a person and

104
00:05:55.140 --> 00:06:00.030
you want me to have some level of life
balance, and be compassionate to my needs,

105
00:06:00.030 --> 00:06:04.790
my desires, my fears, and
to me having a life outside of this place.

106
00:06:05.990 --> 00:06:10.125
The final C, and when I look at these
things the first one, character

107
00:06:10.125 --> 00:06:14.005
is definitely first and this one,
the seventh, is definitely the seventh.

108
00:06:14.005 --> 00:06:18.115
The other ones can kind of be mixed
around but number seven is contribution.

109
00:06:18.115 --> 00:06:23.365
What the people in my research survey said
was, once you get to be a true leader,

110
00:06:23.365 --> 00:06:28.235
you've got access to resources, you've got
a lot of people that work with you, you've

111
00:06:28.235 --> 00:06:34.570
got some influence, you've got access
to money and other things like that.

112
00:06:34.570 --> 00:06:39.210
That you should take all of those things
that you've got at your disposal and

113
00:06:39.210 --> 00:06:43.900
reinvest them in the future,
to contribute back to your people,

114
00:06:43.900 --> 00:06:47.050
your company, your community,
frankly to the world.

115
00:06:47.050 --> 00:06:51.640
It was about the fact that
leadership is an obligation, but

116
00:06:51.640 --> 00:06:56.530
it's also a tremendous opportunity
to use the resources and

117
00:06:56.530 --> 00:07:00.820
influence you have at your disposal
to make the world a better place.

118
00:07:00.820 --> 00:07:04.380
The big idea here was thinking long-term.

119
00:07:04.380 --> 00:07:07.650
The words I like to use is you
must plant the seeds of trees

120
00:07:07.650 --> 00:07:09.270
under which you may never sit,

121
00:07:09.270 --> 00:07:13.510
that a great leader isn't just thinking
about how can we maximize profit today?

122
00:07:13.510 --> 00:07:15.840
How can I increase revenue this month?

123
00:07:15.840 --> 00:07:19.270
Yes, you worry about those things but
you're also saying how can I build up my

124
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:22.680
leaders so that I have a great leadership
team five, ten years from now?

125
00:07:22.680 --> 00:07:27.800
What do I need to do today to ensure
the company is strong a decade from now?

126
00:07:27.800 --> 00:07:32.430
What sort of tough decisions can I make
right now that will be a positive impact

127
00:07:32.430 --> 00:07:36.860
on my people, on my community,
on the sustainability of the Earth?

128
00:07:36.860 --> 00:07:42.030
It's really sitting back and asking, what
is the legacy I want to leave as a leader?

129
00:07:42.030 --> 00:07:43.170
What's the impact I want to have?

130
00:07:43.170 --> 00:07:45.350
Not only today on the success
of the business or

131
00:07:45.350 --> 00:07:50.910
the organization, but a decade from now,
two decades, three decades from now.

132
00:07:50.910 --> 00:07:55.640
How will I impact people, touch them,
assist them, contribute to them so

133
00:07:55.640 --> 00:07:59.280
that I can leave a strong,
positive legacy?

134
00:07:59.280 --> 00:08:02.580
Based on all of my research and
working with companies for

135
00:08:02.580 --> 00:08:06.820
20 years teaching leadership, those
are seven of the key characteristics that

136
00:08:06.820 --> 00:08:10.230
people look for
in a leader they would willingly follow.

137
00:08:10.230 --> 00:08:14.610
Now, to be a great leader, it's important
to think about those characteristics but

138
00:08:14.610 --> 00:08:17.620
also think about the other things
that are important to you.

139
00:08:17.620 --> 00:08:22.030
What the leadership values, the attitudes,
the attributes, the characteristics that

140
00:08:22.030 --> 00:08:26.630
you feel are critical for you to become
the kind of leader that you want to be?

141
00:08:26.630 --> 00:08:30.360
It's fascinating to me that in teaching
my classes all over the world,

142
00:08:30.360 --> 00:08:34.080
I will usually ask at the beginning
of a leadership class,

143
00:08:34.080 --> 00:08:39.350
how many of you in the room currently have
a written list of your core leadership

144
00:08:39.350 --> 00:08:44.010
values that you use to guide your
behavior on a daily basis and

145
00:08:44.010 --> 00:08:46.032
be the kind of leader
you've always wanted to be?

146
00:08:46.032 --> 00:08:53.240
Perhaps 5% or less of the people in
the room usually raise their hands.

147
00:08:53.240 --> 00:08:57.140
The major lesson from this is, you've
gotta take the time to look at those

148
00:08:57.140 --> 00:09:01.100
characteristics I just shared with you and
your own personal values, and

149
00:09:01.100 --> 00:09:03.710
what you've seen the best
leaders you've worked with, and

150
00:09:03.710 --> 00:09:07.418
create your own personal
leadership competency model.

151
00:09:07.418 --> 00:09:12.399
A list of the things you want to live to
be the kind of leader that you hope to be.

152
00:09:12.399 --> 00:09:16.368
Now it's time to do the workshop, I hope
you find it very valuable and helpful.

153
00:09:16.368 --> 00:09:26.368
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: The Formula for Business Excellence
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.302
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03.302 --> 00:00:05.699
In this session, I would like
to share with you my formula for

3
00:00:05.699 --> 00:00:07.090
business excellence.

4
00:00:07.090 --> 00:00:11.274
This is based on more than 20 years
of research, reading, studying and

5
00:00:11.274 --> 00:00:14.718
working with literally hundreds
of companies, looking for

6
00:00:14.718 --> 00:00:19.255
the pattern of what do only the best of
the best do to build a successful company?

7
00:00:19.255 --> 00:00:27.369
The formula is T+C (T+C+ECF)
x DE = Business Excellence.

8
00:00:27.369 --> 00:00:28.794
Let's start with the T.

9
00:00:28.794 --> 00:00:30.550
The T stands for Talent.

10
00:00:30.550 --> 00:00:33.129
All right,
it's pretty straightforward to me.

11
00:00:33.129 --> 00:00:35.889
The success of your business
is directly tied to

12
00:00:35.889 --> 00:00:40.700
the quality of the people that you
can get, grow, and keep on your team.

13
00:00:40.700 --> 00:00:44.280
Which means then, that talent acquisition,
talent development, and

14
00:00:44.280 --> 00:00:48.190
talent retention should be
a major strategic objective.

15
00:00:48.190 --> 00:00:50.288
You wanna get the best people you
can possibly get on your team.

16
00:00:50.288 --> 00:00:53.710
Now, this doesn't mean that everybody
has to have 11 advance degrees from IB

17
00:00:53.710 --> 00:00:54.489
league schools.

18
00:00:54.489 --> 00:00:57.810
What it means is for
the position I'm hiring,

19
00:00:57.810 --> 00:01:02.168
I wanna get someone who can do
that job really, really well.

20
00:01:02.168 --> 00:01:05.216
Whether it is the CFO,
whether it's a sales person,

21
00:01:05.216 --> 00:01:08.876
whether it's someone who answers
the phones, whatever it is,

22
00:01:08.876 --> 00:01:13.319
these are all different skill sets and
different skill level requirements.

23
00:01:13.319 --> 00:01:15.367
But whatever job you're hiring for,

24
00:01:15.367 --> 00:01:18.762
you want to find somebody that's
super talented in that area.

25
00:01:18.762 --> 00:01:22.649
Another thing to think about
is that many businesses today,

26
00:01:22.649 --> 00:01:28.712
their competition has a product that's
close, similar, maybe even better.

27
00:01:28.712 --> 00:01:32.410
Their competition has something that's
priced similarly, maybe less expensive.

28
00:01:32.410 --> 00:01:34.940
They can copy you on your marketing.

29
00:01:34.940 --> 00:01:36.209
If you've got a great website,

30
00:01:36.209 --> 00:01:39.580
they'll have something up that looks
like it within a couple of hours.

31
00:01:39.580 --> 00:01:43.770
Distribution, most, every business
can distribute anywhere in the world.

32
00:01:43.770 --> 00:01:48.090
In other words, a lot of the things that
used to differentiate businesses, and

33
00:01:48.090 --> 00:01:53.170
allow them to compete successfully in
the marketplace have been wiped out.

34
00:01:53.170 --> 00:01:56.210
They're parity,
everybody can do about the same thing,

35
00:01:56.210 --> 00:01:59.944
which means that the quality of
the people that you can get on your team.

36
00:01:59.944 --> 00:02:04.171
And the relationships they create with
your customers is one of the only

37
00:02:04.171 --> 00:02:06.853
sustainable competitive advantages left.

38
00:02:06.853 --> 00:02:11.800
The C stands for culture, and
there are two parts to culture.

39
00:02:11.800 --> 00:02:14.760
The first part is what do employees want?

40
00:02:14.760 --> 00:02:18.900
Based on the firms of endearment study,
the Great Places to Work study and

41
00:02:18.900 --> 00:02:21.937
a national Gallup poll of 23
million American workers.

42
00:02:21.937 --> 00:02:24.752
Basically, there's nine
things that people look for

43
00:02:24.752 --> 00:02:28.297
in the kind of culture they would
get excited about, engaged in, and

44
00:02:28.297 --> 00:02:30.880
would make them want to
work at a certain company.

45
00:02:30.880 --> 00:02:32.218
First one is fun.

46
00:02:32.218 --> 00:02:36.299
And that doesn't mean that we got
a rock-climbing wall, and masseuses,

47
00:02:36.299 --> 00:02:37.070
and sushi.

48
00:02:37.070 --> 00:02:39.000
Although, those things are nice.

49
00:02:39.000 --> 00:02:41.380
What it means is that people
enjoy where they work.

50
00:02:41.380 --> 00:02:45.780
And the best test of this is do people
smile just as much when they come to work

51
00:02:45.780 --> 00:02:47.790
as when they leave?

52
00:02:47.790 --> 00:02:49.540
When your employees get
there in the morning,

53
00:02:49.540 --> 00:02:51.250
do they smile when they
get out of the car?

54
00:02:51.250 --> 00:02:52.680
Are they looking forward
to coming to work?

55
00:02:52.680 --> 00:02:54.720
Do they enjoy the people
they're working with?

56
00:02:54.720 --> 00:02:57.670
And at the end of the day, are they
smiling when they leave to go home?

57
00:02:57.670 --> 00:02:59.560
Of course, they wanna go home,
they want their weekend,

58
00:02:59.560 --> 00:03:03.850
they want their vacation, but
they also enjoy where they work.

59
00:03:03.850 --> 00:03:05.000
Number two is very close.

60
00:03:05.000 --> 00:03:06.000
It's friends.

61
00:03:06.000 --> 00:03:07.440
Do I like the people I work with?

62
00:03:07.440 --> 00:03:09.190
Do I enjoy being around them?

63
00:03:09.190 --> 00:03:09.890
Are they fun?

64
00:03:09.890 --> 00:03:10.870
Are they nice?

65
00:03:10.870 --> 00:03:12.610
Do they treat me with respect?

66
00:03:12.610 --> 00:03:15.350
Do I consider the people
I work with my friends,

67
00:03:15.350 --> 00:03:18.490
some of them even
possibly my best friends?

68
00:03:18.490 --> 00:03:21.908
Number three sort of ties the first three
together, and that's family atmosphere.

69

00:08:32.780 --> 00:08:36.470

the number one factor in highly engaged,

where we're constantly talking

And there's five things there,

I'm gonna hold someone accountable for a

00:11:15.790 --> 00:11:19.090
I'm talking about mission critical things
that gotta get done that are gonna

00:11:19.090 --> 00:11:20.830

00:11:20.830 --> 00:11:23.210

00:11:23.210 --> 00:11:25.155
I have to do three things for them.

217
00:11:25.155 --> 00:11:28.460
Number one is 100% clarity.

00:11:28.460 --> 00:11:31.390
I need to sit down with that person

00:11:31.390 --> 00:11:35.662

220
00:11:35.662 --> 00:11:41.330
I've gotta give them, again, key result

00:11:41.330 --> 00:11:43.100
And the key idea around metrics here and

key result areas is binary,

00:11:47.460 --> 00:11:51.210
It's black or it's white,

Another big phrase that I use all

00:11:56.610 --> 00:11:59.470
If you're gonna have
a culture of accountability,

00:11:59.470 --> 00:12:04.630
you've gotta be really clear and get 100%
clarity on what success looks like and

00:12:04.630 --> 00:12:07.610

00:12:07.610 --> 00:12:11.440
In addition to that, you've also

00:12:14.740 --> 00:12:18.210

That scares me.

00:15:40.710 --> 00:15:45.170
And the reason is because for
most people, tracking equals punishment.

295
00:15:45.170 --> 00:15:46.970
We'll come back to that in a minute.

296
00:15:46.970 --> 00:15:51.135
In the third group, maybe 10,
15%, hopefully 10 or 5.

297
00:15:51.135 --> 00:15:54.109
When you tell them you're gonna do this,
we're gonna assign you goals, and

298
00:15:54.109 --> 00:15:56.091
we're gonna track them and
post them everywhere.

299
00:15:56.091 --> 00:15:58.646
They go, no, you can't do that,
it's not fair.

300
00:15:58.646 --> 00:16:01.099
And they fall on the ground like
a two year old with a wet diaper and

301
00:16:01.099 --> 00:16:02.430
start crying and falling around.

302
00:16:02.430 --> 00:16:03.750
And what you do is you look down at them,

303
00:16:03.750 --> 00:16:05.970
you go it's been a pleasure
working with you.

304
00:16:05.970 --> 00:16:08.770
And then you make them
available to industry.

305
00:16:08.770 --> 00:16:13.310
The reason is they've just told you I'm
mediocre and everybody's gonna know it.

306
00:16:13.310 --> 00:16:17.150
When you put my goals up there, I'm gonna
consistently be yellow, red, yellow, red,

307
00:16:17.150 --> 00:16:18.380
yellow, red.

308
00:16:18.380 --> 00:16:23.210
And everyone will know it and
I will have to leave or you will fire me.

309
00:16:23.210 --> 00:16:26.630
So, again let's come back to
that big group in the middle and

310
00:16:26.630 --> 00:16:31.430
step number four then is because
people are freaked out that they think

311
00:16:31.430 --> 00:16:34.960
tracking equals punishment,
I'm tracking you so I can yell at you.

312
00:16:34.960 --> 00:16:38.650
I'm tracking at you so I can withhold
bonus, you don't get a promotion or

313
00:16:38.650 --> 00:16:41.700
whatever it might be, but
tracking equals punishment.

314
00:16:41.700 --> 00:16:46.140
Step number four is coach,
mentor, train and support.

315
00:16:46.140 --> 00:16:49.800
In other words, I'm not gonna yell at
you when you go from green to yellow,

316
00:16:49.800 --> 00:16:51.040
I'm gonna help you.

317
00:16:51.040 --> 00:16:54.400
People are gonna parachute in from the sky
to do everything they can to assist you,

318
00:16:54.400 --> 00:16:56.730
to help you, to get you back on green.

319
00:16:56.730 --> 00:17:00.600
So, tracking doesn't equal punishment,
tracking equals help.

320
00:17:00.600 --> 00:17:03.450
And it will take those people
a little while to realize it, but

321
00:17:03.450 --> 00:17:07.790
once they realize, every time I
slip to yellow, I get support,

322
00:17:07.790 --> 00:17:11.970
I get training, I get a mentor,
I get a coach, I get more resources,

323
00:17:11.970 --> 00:17:16.920
people help me get back into green, it's
crazy they're gonna want more tracking.

324
00:17:16.920 --> 00:17:22.040
And then the last element number five,
is reward success lavishly and

325
00:17:22.040 --> 00:17:23.700
deal decisively with mediocrity.

326
00:17:23.700 --> 00:17:26.060
And when I say lavishly,
I'm not talking about running out and

327
00:17:26.060 --> 00:17:29.240
throwing hundred dollar bills everywhere,
employee of the month,

328
00:17:29.240 --> 00:17:34.640
dinner out with her significant other,
some sort of a small gift or a prize.

329
00:17:34.640 --> 00:17:37.260
And maybe money, maybe a bonus,
maybe a promotion.

330
00:17:37.260 --> 00:17:42.180
But you want to reinforce positive
behavior by letting people

331
00:17:42.180 --> 00:17:45.750
know that when they make a commitment
they take on accountability and

332
00:17:45.750 --> 00:17:49.410
they deliver on their promise, that
that's exactly what you want from them.

333
00:17:49.410 --> 00:17:54.450
So you wanna make them a model to the rest
of the company of accountability.

334
00:17:54.450 --> 00:17:57.470
On the other hand, the folks that
consistently don't do it, and

335
00:17:57.470 --> 00:17:59.610
you're coaching them,
you're training them, you're supporting,

336
00:17:59.610 --> 00:18:03.040
you're doing everything you can to help
them and everybody else sees that.

337
00:18:03.040 --> 00:18:06.700
They see you make the effort
to help them be successful and

338
00:18:06.700 --> 00:18:10.370
they just keep staying in yellow and
red and red and red.

339
00:18:10.370 --> 00:18:13.890
When you let them go,
everybody understands why.

340
00:18:13.890 --> 00:18:16.480
They see that you helped them,
they see that you supported them,

341
00:18:16.480 --> 00:18:20.110
they see that you tried really hard,
and that they didn't make it.

342
00:18:20.110 --> 00:18:23.320
It's a really important thing to
remember this, when you let someone go,

343
00:18:23.320 --> 00:18:28.140
terminate someone, everybody else in
the company looks to see how you did it.

344
00:18:28.140 --> 00:18:29.670
Did you treat them fairly?

345
00:18:29.670 --> 00:18:31.230
Did they know it was coming?

346
00:18:31.230 --> 00:18:32.420
Did you give them help?

347
00:18:32.420 --> 00:18:34.560
Did you give them corrective action?

348
00:18:34.560 --> 00:18:37.740
If you do all that through Coach Better
Training Support people will think it's

349
00:18:37.740 --> 00:18:38.470
very fair.

350
00:18:38.470 --> 00:18:40.990
They'll see that you
tried hard to help them.

351
00:18:40.990 --> 00:18:43.700
However though,
if all of a sudden somebody looks up and

352
00:18:43.700 --> 00:18:44.600
like hey, where's Bob?

353
00:18:44.600 --> 00:18:46.790
And you go, he got vaporized.

354
00:18:46.790 --> 00:18:47.960
What do you mean he got vaporized?

355
00:18:47.960 --> 00:18:50.880
He was here a minute ago,
he's gone, they just terminated him.

356
00:18:50.880 --> 00:18:51.820
And the other person say, but

357
00:18:51.820 --> 00:18:56.770
I thought Bob got all exceeds last
report when they did his review.

358
00:18:56.770 --> 00:18:59.079
Wasn't he reviewed at the highest level?

359
00:18:59.079 --> 00:19:02.775
Well if they fired Bob and
he was all exceeds and I'm all exceeds and

360
00:19:02.775 --> 00:19:07.131
there was no reason they fired Bob, or
at least there's nothing I know about,

361
00:19:07.131 --> 00:19:09.049
what happens is they get fearful.

362
00:19:09.049 --> 00:19:11.069
They think that I could be next,
even though I'm doing a good job,

363
00:19:11.069 --> 00:19:11.876
no one's said anything.

364
00:19:11.876 --> 00:19:14.470
No one said anything to Bob,
now Bob's gone.

365
00:19:14.470 --> 00:19:18.500
And people when they're fearful,
don't do great work.

366
00:19:18.500 --> 00:19:20.060
They put their head down, they're scared.

367
00:19:20.060 --> 00:19:23.230
They do the least amount of work they
can cuz they don't wanna get in trouble.

368
00:19:23.230 --> 00:19:25.220
And they're constantly talking and

369
00:19:25.220 --> 00:19:28.580
worrying and
getting everybody else stressed out.

370
00:19:28.580 --> 00:19:32.550
So, the coach, mentor, train, and
support allows you to show everyone else

371
00:19:32.550 --> 00:19:36.210
we're fair here, we treated them
with respect, we supported them, but

372
00:19:36.210 --> 00:19:37.750
they just couldn't make the grade.

373
00:19:37.750 --> 00:19:40.305
Those are the five things it takes to
create a culture of accountability,

374
00:19:40.305 --> 00:19:43.812
100% clarity plus appropriate
authority and resources,

375
00:19:43.812 --> 00:19:49.410
100% agreement, track and post,
coach, mentor, train, support,

376
00:19:49.410 --> 00:19:55.520
reward success lavishly, deal immediately
and directly with mediocrity.

377
00:19:55.520 --> 00:19:59.660
So, there you have it, my formula for
business excellence, talent, plus culture,

378
00:19:59.660 --> 00:20:03.380
plus extreme customer focus,
multiplied by disciplined execution.

379
00:20:03.380 --> 00:20:07.832
These aren't the only four things you need
to run a great business, but, what I will

380
00:20:07.832 --> 00:20:12.115
tell you is, they're four foundational
fundamental things you got to do well.

381
00:20:12.115 --> 00:20:14.876
On a scale of one to ten
you should be solid nine or

382
00:20:14.876 --> 00:20:17.100
ten on all four of these things.

383
00:20:17.100 --> 00:20:20.608
And I can say that with extreme
confidence because I've looked hundreds,

384
00:20:20.608 --> 00:20:21.895
of hundreds of companies.

385
00:20:21.895 --> 00:20:24.124
I've read thousands of books and

386
00:20:24.124 --> 00:20:28.898
when you look at those there's a very
clear pattern that companies that

387
00:20:28.898 --> 00:20:33.688
are successful over the long term do
these four things exceeding well.

388
00:20:33.688 --> 00:20:40.480
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: A very powerful idea that focuses on understanding that handful of essential interactions that must be delivered flawlessly in order to create highly engaged, loyal and satisfied customers.
episodes.title: Moments of Truth
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:03.110 --> 00:00:06.949
In this session I wanna share with
you a really big business idea.

2
00:00:06.949 --> 00:00:09.192
Many times when I'm teaching my courses,

3
00:00:09.192 --> 00:00:12.270
folks say this was the most
important thing they learned.

4
00:00:12.270 --> 00:00:14.230
It's called the moments of truth.

5
00:00:14.230 --> 00:00:18.760
And it was basically developed by
a gentleman years ago named Jan Collison.

6
00:00:18.760 --> 00:00:21.175
He was the CEO of Scandinavian Airway.

7
00:00:21.175 --> 00:00:23.010
He'd just come in to take it over.

8
00:00:23.010 --> 00:00:27.930
And the airway was in some pretty
serious financial trouble as many are.

9
00:00:27.930 --> 00:00:31.533
And he looked at it and said if we're
going to rebuild this company why don't we

10
00:00:31.533 --> 00:00:33.180
do it with the very best customers.

11
00:00:33.180 --> 00:00:36.582
I mean if we're going to chase a new
market let's go to the market where

12
00:00:36.582 --> 00:00:40.980
the best customers are, the ones that
every airline would love to have.

13
00:00:40.980 --> 00:00:44.190
In the airline industry,
that's the frequent business traveler,

14
00:00:44.190 --> 00:00:47.135
[LAUGH] somebody like me,
who's on the road 200 days a year.

15
00:00:47.135 --> 00:00:51.062
They get in and out quick, they usually
don't have much luggage, they pay whatever

16
00:00:51.062 --> 00:00:54.580
fee they have to for the ticket,
cuz they gotta be in the next place.

17
00:00:54.580 --> 00:00:57.844
They're the ones that, if you wanted them
that would be the client you go after

18
00:00:57.844 --> 00:00:59.485
cuz they come back over and over again.

19
00:00:59.485 --> 00:01:01.750
They spend lots of money and
they're easy to deal with.

20
00:01:01.750 --> 00:01:03.350
We all want clients like that.

21
00:01:03.350 --> 00:01:08.450
So what he did is he look at and said
looks like all the touch points we have

22
00:01:08.450 --> 00:01:11.170
with someone that flies on our airline.

23
00:01:11.170 --> 00:01:15.090
From when they get on the website or
make a phone call and initiate.

24
00:01:15.090 --> 00:01:18.300
Trying to get a ticket all
the way to when they get home,

25
00:01:18.300 --> 00:01:22.720
hopefully with their luggage, and
hopefully having a great experience.

26
00:01:22.720 --> 00:01:25.760
Then he said,
out of all those touch points,

27
00:01:25.760 --> 00:01:29.840
let's figure out the three,
four, five moments of truth.

28
00:01:29.840 --> 00:01:33.561
The stuff we have to do flawlessly
if we're gonna take that person and

29
00:01:33.561 --> 00:01:36.050
turn them into a customer evangelist.

30
00:01:36.050 --> 00:01:38.770
Somebody who loves our airlines,
will only fly with us.

31
00:01:38.770 --> 00:01:40.720
Comes back over and over again.

32
00:01:40.720 --> 00:01:42.560
Tells all their friends to fly with us.

33
00:01:42.560 --> 00:01:45.310
Tells all their business
associates to fly with us.

34
00:01:45.310 --> 00:01:48.290
We wanna make sure that out
of all the touch points,

35
00:01:48.290 --> 00:01:52.700
we figure out what those key moments of
truth are, and then we do them flawlessly.

36
00:01:52.700 --> 00:01:54.780
Now let me give you an example
that'll bring this home,

37
00:01:54.780 --> 00:01:58.490
and it's the same example I use every
time I teach this, restaurants.

38
00:01:59.550 --> 00:02:02.435
I did the research,
sat down one day and I counted it,

39
00:02:02.435 --> 00:02:06.429
and if you go out to dinner with your
family or by yourself or with friends.

40
00:02:06.429 --> 00:02:12.070
There is about a 170 touch points
in a normal door restaurant.

41
00:02:12.070 --> 00:02:13.960
Is it easy to find the place?

42
00:02:13.960 --> 00:02:16.580
Is easy to get in and
out of the drive way?

43
00:02:16.580 --> 00:02:17.840
Is there good signage?

44
00:02:17.840 --> 00:02:19.070
Is the parking lot clean?

45
00:02:19.070 --> 00:02:20.930
If it's at night, Is it well lite?

46
00:02:20.930 --> 00:02:22.530
Is the shrubbery attractive?

47
00:02:22.530 --> 00:02:23.790
The landscaping?

48
00:02:23.790 --> 00:02:24.990
Is the temperature right?

49
00:02:24.990 --> 00:02:27.060
Is the music too loud or too soft?

50
00:02:27.060 --> 00:02:29.390
Do they greet you when
you come in the door?

51
00:02:29.390 --> 00:02:31.710
Are the seats comfortable?

52
00:02:31.710 --> 00:02:34.070
All of these things are touch points.

53
00:02:34.070 --> 00:02:38.240
But in pretty much every restaurant
on the face of the earth,

54
00:02:38.240 --> 00:02:41.330
there's only really four moments of truth.

55
00:02:41.330 --> 00:02:45.160
Four things they have to nail,
just absolutely do perfectly.

56
00:02:45.160 --> 00:02:47.720
If you are gonna become
a patron of that restaurant.

57
00:02:47.720 --> 00:02:50.100
Love it, come back all the time,
bring your friends,

58
00:02:50.100 --> 00:02:52.280
bring your family,
tell everybody about it.

59
00:02:52.280 --> 00:02:55.070
Just four things they have
to do exceedingly well,

60
00:02:55.070 --> 00:02:57.260
the four moments of truth for
a restaurant.

61
00:02:57.260 --> 00:03:00.510
Here they are, and
I've asked hundreds of audiences this and

62
00:03:00.510 --> 00:03:03.070
they almost always nail it immediately.

63
00:03:03.070 --> 00:03:08.100
Good quality food, reasonable prices,
good service, cleanliness.

64
00:03:08.100 --> 00:03:09.390
That's pretty much it.

65
00:03:09.390 --> 00:03:10.890
I have people say ambiance and everything.

66
00:03:10.890 --> 00:03:12.420
Those are touch points.

67
00:03:12.420 --> 00:03:15.140
But if you're gonna go to
a restaurant over and over again,

68
00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:19.650
you gotta get really good food at
a reasonable price with great service, and

69
00:03:19.650 --> 00:03:22.320
the place has to be immaculately clean.

70
00:03:22.320 --> 00:03:27.260
Now let me give you a scenario, let's say
we all go out to dinner together, you,

71
00:03:27.260 --> 00:03:28.504
me, some friends.

72
00:03:28.504 --> 00:03:32.210
And I happen to like sushi so
I use sushi restaurants as an example.

73
00:03:32.210 --> 00:03:35.310
And we get there and it's super easy
to get at, it's right in the corner,

74
00:03:35.310 --> 00:03:38.670
easy to find, big sign, big parking spots.

75
00:03:38.670 --> 00:03:40.190
We go in the evening, it's well lit.

76
00:03:40.190 --> 00:03:43.266
We come up and all the shrubbery and
landscaping is gorgeous,

77
00:03:43.266 --> 00:03:44.517
they've got a koi pond.

78
00:03:44.517 --> 00:03:45.570
You know, it's just stunning.

79
00:03:45.570 --> 00:03:48.831
We walk in,
unbelievably polite when we get there.

80
00:03:48.831 --> 00:03:52.440
Beautiful ambiance,
nice artwork on the walls and everything.

81
00:03:52.440 --> 00:03:54.380
They seat us, the menu comes.

82
00:03:54.380 --> 00:03:58.195
We look at it and the prices,
I mean, they're really reasonable.

83
00:03:58.195 --> 00:04:00.998
And, you know, while we're sitting
there they bring us our drinks,

84
00:04:00.998 --> 00:04:02.623
they keep our sakai hot, our beer cold.

85
00:04:02.623 --> 00:04:04.717
I mean the service is amazing.

86
00:04:04.717 --> 00:04:05.795
The food comes out.

87
00:04:05.795 --> 00:04:08.020
It's the best sushi you've ever had.

88
00:04:08.020 --> 00:04:11.280
It's incredibly fresh,
it's beautifully prepared, it's stunning.

89
00:04:11.280 --> 00:04:13.610
I mean, you're having an amazing dinner.

90
00:04:13.610 --> 00:04:16.170
And then you excuse yourself to get up and
go use the restroom, and

91
00:04:16.170 --> 00:04:19.610
you walk in there, and it looks like
no one has cleaned it in four years.

92
00:04:19.610 --> 00:04:23.247
It's disgusting, it smells bad,
there's stuff all over the floor,

93
00:04:23.247 --> 00:04:25.377
there's cockroaches crawling around.

94
00:04:25.377 --> 00:04:28.522
And as you walk out of the bathroom,
you're going God, it was horrible,

95
00:04:28.522 --> 00:04:29.762
you'd see a rat run across.

96
00:04:29.762 --> 00:04:32.688
Are you ever,
ever going to that restaurant again?

97
00:04:32.688 --> 00:04:35.205
No, but here's the key point.

98
00:04:35.205 --> 00:04:40.529
They got 169 out of 170 touch points,
perfectly, they nailed three

99
00:04:40.529 --> 00:04:45.853
of the four moments truth flawlessly but
they missed one moment of truth and

100
00:04:45.853 --> 00:04:49.930
because of that they have now
lost the customer forever.

101
00:04:51.030 --> 00:04:53.070
Here's the really important point,

102
00:04:53.070 --> 00:04:55.740
you have moments of truth
in your business too.

103
00:04:55.740 --> 00:04:59.580
Three, four,
five maybe six things you've gotta do.

104
00:04:59.580 --> 00:05:02.090
And I use the word over and
over again, flawlessly.

105
00:05:02.090 --> 00:05:07.520
Absolutely perfect if you want to
turn your customers into raving fans.

106
00:05:07.520 --> 00:05:11.030
People who drive lots of new business
to you, spend lots of money with you.

107
00:05:11.030 --> 00:05:13.520
Love being with their,
being there with you.

108
00:05:13.520 --> 00:05:15.033
And again, there's only a few.

109
00:05:15.033 --> 00:05:15.925
It's not 100.

110
00:05:15.925 --> 00:05:20.010
There's a handful of things
that you have to do flawlessly.

111
00:05:20.010 --> 00:05:23.978
So, the first question you need to think
about is, what are your moments of truth?

112
00:05:23.978 --> 00:05:26.860
What are the things you
have to do perfectly?

113
00:05:26.860 --> 00:05:28.370
Give you another example real quick,

114
00:05:28.370 --> 00:05:33.370
it's like making a cake,
if the cake batter taste disgusting,

115
00:05:33.370 --> 00:05:37.420
it doesn't matter how beautiful
the icing is, nobody wants a bite.

116
00:05:37.420 --> 00:05:39.330
If the cake batter is heavenly,

117
00:05:39.330 --> 00:05:44.720
just delicious, you could glop icing
all over it, people still want a piece.

118
00:05:44.720 --> 00:05:48.210
But, if you make a beautiful
cake that tastes delicious and

119
00:05:48.210 --> 00:05:52.870
put magnificent icing on it,
everybody wants a piece.

120
00:05:52.870 --> 00:05:55.230
The moments of truth are the cake batter.

121
00:05:55.230 --> 00:05:57.430
All of the other stuff is touch points.

122
00:05:57.430 --> 00:06:01.820
But if you don't get the cake
batter right, nothing else matters.

123
00:06:01.820 --> 00:06:05.386
Couple of other things to think
about with moments of truth.

124
00:06:05.386 --> 00:06:09.923
Number one, the only person you can truly
tell you what the moments truth are,

125
00:06:09.923 --> 00:06:11.660
are the customers.

126
00:06:11.660 --> 00:06:14.132
So ask them, what are the three or

127
00:06:14.132 --> 00:06:19.150
four most important things we need
to do to keep you highly satisfied?

128
00:06:19.150 --> 00:06:22.470
And I will challenge you that if you go
out and ask a bunch of your customers, or

129
00:06:22.470 --> 00:06:25.330
your very best customers,
they're gonna come back and

130
00:06:25.330 --> 00:06:29.150
tell you the same handful of things,
all of them are, over and over again.

131
00:06:29.150 --> 00:06:31.300
And you will get a very clear pattern,

132
00:06:31.300 --> 00:06:34.700
which has just told you what your
